The size of this vessel is one hundred twenty inches in diameter with an overall length of thirty feet  no inches (120 X 30). It has a total volume calculated to be 1,749 cubic feet with a capacity of 71,159 pounds of liquid ammonia at a saturated condition of +85?F / 150 psig. 
The duration of the release used for calculations is ten minutes for a release rate of 3,910 pounds of ammonia per minute. RMP*Comp wase used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.
	
 
3.7.2.	Alternate Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario (OCA-2) is the direct release of ammonia vapor from the largest pressure relief valve. This scenario was chosen as the most probable source of an ammonia release that would have the potential of offsite consequences based on the number of relief valves and on the high summer operating pressures. The size of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (300 lbs/min) having a worst-case release-duration of ten minutes. RMP*Comp was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint. 
This scenario is used for RMP Submit since it is the most probable occurrence although the duration is expected to be significantly shorter due to the refrigerating effect on reducing pressures.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility follows the EPAs 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHAs 29CFR1910.119 Process Safety Management Program.  The documentation requirements of these two programs have been consolidated in the documenting and record filing process. 

The Accident Prevention Program documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program. 

The following identifies the practices and procedures for:
 
?	Process Safety Information
?	Process Hazard Analysis
?	Operating Procedures
?	Training
?	Mechanical Integrity
?	Management of Change
?	Pre-Startup Review
?	Compliance Audits
?	Incident Investigations
?	Employee Partic

t at this facility.
2.5.2.	Compliance Audits
The PSM Manager conducts PSM compliance audits every three years for the entire program. Annual updates will also be performed for various elements of the RMP by the Environmental Manager.	

3.0	HAZARD ASSESSMENT							
3.1 	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY	
Anhydrous ammonia is the toxic substance for which this hazard assessment is done. The LOC for ammonia is 200 ppm.  The OCA establishes Areas of Concern with a radius of 2.3 miles for the Worst-case Scenario and a radius of 0.1 miles for the Alternate Release Scenario. The affected populations are estimated at 38,020 people for the Worst-case Scenario and 11 people for the Alternate Release Scenario. There are environmental receptors within the Areas of Concern that could possibly be affected. 

RELEASE SCENARIOS					
3.7.1.	Worst Case Scenario
The worst-case release scenario (OCA-1) used in this assessment identifies the medium-temperature re-circulator (V-2) as the pump-down vessel with the potential to hold a large quantity of ammonia at higher pressures than the other vessels. This scenario looks at a release occurring from this vessel during a pump-down procedure when this vessel may be nearly full of liquid ammonia. During normal operation, the inventory of ammonia is continuously circulated throughout the refrigeration system. Normal vessel inventories are usually between ten and thirty percent of individual vessel capacity. 
The design of this vessel allows it to be used as a pump-down ammonia holding vessel during infrequent installation or maintenance procedures. The maximum intended holding capacity is eighty percent of total volume. It is only during this pump-down procedure when the greatest volume of ammonia is present, providing the opportunity for the worst-case scenario. The worst-case release scenario is based on a rupture that occurs on the vessel side of the isolation valve for the 4 HPL line that feeds the medium-temperature recirculator causing the released qu

fety and to minimize risks to the community, the environment, the employees, and the facility.  Operations at the facility comply with all aspects of the PSM Program.   
2.3.	COMMITMENT
Management is fully committed to the Risk Management Program and sees it as a vital and integrated part of general operations.  Management does provide the support and the resources to implement these procedures on an ongoing basis. Furthermore, the company understands that it is important to convey its commitment to employees and supervisors.  Some of the ways that this is accomplished are:
	by verbal instructions when employees are hired
	by strict enforcement of practices, procedures, and programs for operating and maintaining the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure safety 
	by the example of the site and corporate management
	by recognizing employees who excel in the RMP
	by training and drills 
Steps, such as these, demonstrate the commitment of corporate management to enforcing employee participation in and compliance with this RMP Program.  	

2.4.	FOCUS
The Facilities Manager has the responsibility to oversee 13 functional areas: 
	Employee participation
	Process safety information
	Process hazard analysis
	Standard operating procedures	
	Training
	Contractors
	Pre-startup review
	Mechanical integrity
	Hot work
	Management of change
	Incident investigation
	Emergency response plan
	Compliance audits
The Facilities Manager is involved in planning, staffing, and reviewing these areas and is charged with actively managing compliance with these regulations. These topics are described in more detail in Section 4, Accident Prevention Program, as noted in EPA 550-B-98-014.
2.5.	AUDITS AND REVIEWS			
2.5.1.	Policy
The companys policy is to take federal regulations seriously, knowing that these regulations can protect life and property.  The Environmental Manager will review RMP compliance on an on-going basis. Section 7 outlines the responsibilities of managemen

xic substance, liquefied under pressure. The definitions and parameters for the following release scenarios are based on the Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration as described in Chapter 4: Off-site Consequence Analysis.

The worst-case release scenario (OCA-1) used in this assessment identifies the medium temperature re-circulator (V-2) as the vessel with the potential to hold the largest quantity of ammonia. This is based on the system design using this vessel as a pump-down holding receiver. The worst-case release scenario is based on a rupture that occurs on the vessel side of the isolation valve for the 4 HPL line that feeds the medium-temperature recirculator causing the released quantity to be equal to 80% of the total vessel volume with no piping volume included.
The alternative release scenario (OCA-2) is the direct release of ammonia vapor from the largest pressure relief valve. This scenario was chosen as the most probable source of an ammonia release that would have the potential of offsite consequences based on the number of relief valves and on the high summer operating pressures. The size of the release is based on the rated capacity of the pressure relief valve (300 lbs/min) having a worst-case release-duration of ten minutes.

MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
2.1.	PURPOSE 
This facility has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program. 
Plant Manager
This is the person with overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the program. He/she is assisted by the PSM Manager, Facilities Manager and/or Utilities Supervisor, and Environmental Manager, but the ultimate responsibility remains with the Plant Manager.  
The chart in Section 7 shows the specific duties of each position.

2.2.	SCOPE
The focus of the Management Program is on tracking, reporting, and documenting the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system. This is done to ensure maximum sa

e system are labeled. The identification system is recognized by IIAR. P&ID prints are available for review. Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.
SYSTEM SAFETIES
The ammonia system includes safeties to provide for emergency relief of overpressure, detection equipment in the event of a release of ammonia, automatic control of the ammonia house vent fan and remote compressor shutdown capability.
Each compressor vessel has a dual relief valve assembly which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 300 PSI to a line or lines vented to the outside. A relief valve is also installed in the SR line which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 250 PSI and is vented to the outside.
Relief valves for the vessels are located at the top of the ammonia vessels which will relieve an overpressure in excess of 250 PSI.
Ammonia detectors are located in the following areas and alarm to the 911 monitoring system:
Compressor room #123 (1)
Compressor vent line (1)
High pressure receiver room #123b (2)
Medium temp recirculator room (2)
Accuair #1 for packaging (1)
Accuair #2 for post past (1)
Accuair for smoke house area (1)
Accuair for Browning (1)
Accuair for raw side (1)
Vent line by condenser #5 (1)
Vent line by condenser #7 (1)

The engine room vent fan will turn on in the event of ammonia detection in the engine room, or if the mushroom button outside the engine room door is pushed. The fan can be controlled from the refrigeration office computer.
Should it become necessary to shut down all the compressors, there is a mushroom button located outside the engine room door that will shut down all the compressors when pushed.


1.5.	SUMMARY OF HAZARD ASSESSMENT
This hazard assessment was conducted to meet the RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis requirements for the ammonia refrigeration system. The only RMP regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia and is classified as a to

onfiguration. High-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high-temperature compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed, condensing the vapor to a high-pressure liquid. High-pressure liquid from the condenser is drained to the thermosyphon pilot-receiver and the high-pressure receiver. Saturated condensing temperature is 85°F (150 PSIG) at a corresponding 79°F WB. The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge line and the condenser drain lines go to the high-pressure receiver.
PURGER
This system incorporates an automatic gas purger for removing non-condensable gases from the ammonia system. The presence of non-condensable gases in the condenser penalizes the system performance through the artificial elevation of condensing pressure. The non-condensable gases add their partial pressures to the ammonia partial pressure against which the compressors must pump. The system has several purge point connections, typically at each of the condenser liquid outlet pipes. 
HOT GAS DEFROST
The compressor discharge hot gas is used to defrost the evaporators. During the defrost cycle, the hot gas refrigerant gives up heat and condenses. With the fans shut down, the ability of the coil to transfer that heat to the air is severely limited. Thus, the heat from the hot gas is absorbed by metal in the coil. As the metal absorbs heat, its temperature rises. Once the surface temperature is high enough, any ice and/or frost on the coil surface will melt and drain off. Defrosting the evaporators occurs automatically on a time sequence by individual sequence timers.
EVAPORATORS 
In this facility, the evaporators are fed from liquid pumps. The feed rate is approximately 3:1. This system will circulate three times the amount of the refrigerant needed by the evaporator for the rated capacity. The +20°F high-temperature system includes the glycol chiller, production area, storage coolers, and dock areas.
AMMONIA PIPING AND VALVES
The ammonia piping and valves in th

d volume in this vessel at normal operating level (50% of total vessel volume), is 12.8 cu-ft at saturated liquid temperature of +85°F. All liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel. The thermosyphon oil coolers on the screw compressors are fed from this vessel and return a liquid/gas mix back through the thermosyphon return piping. Most of the liquid ammonia from the condenser drains through this receiver to the high-pressure receiver.
HIGH-PRESSURE RECEIVER
The high-pressure receiver is a vertical vessel. The volume of vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 575.0 cu-ft. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +85°F. The high-pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid coming from the condenser. All liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel. High-pressure liquid is fed from these vessels to the rest of the system. Liquid ammonia is stored in the top of this vessel for thermosyphon oil cooling. The thermosyphon oil coolers on the screw compressors are fed from this vessel and return a liquid/gas mix back through the thermosyphon return piping. All liquid ammonia from the condenser drains to this receiver.
MEDIUM TEMPERATURE RECIRCULATOR 
This recirculator is a horizontal pressure vessel. The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 1749.0 cubic feet. It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +20°F. The high-temp liquid is pumped from this vessel to the production and storage air units where 30% of the liquid mass is evaporated. The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 150 psig. This vessel has connection with the compressors (dry suction) and with the high-temp pumped liquid and the wet suction piping from the evaporators and chillers.

CONDENSERS
The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a draw-through c

refrigerant is a Group II refrigerant. Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system.
Engine room electrical classification is NEMA-1.
SYSTEM OPERATING RANGES
1.	Suction Pressure (28 psig  32 psig, with a set point of 30 psig) 
2.	Discharge Pressure (90 psig  190 psig with a set point of 150 psig)
3.	Compressor Oil Pressure (120 psig  - 135 psig)
4.	Compressor  Oil Temperature (56 deg F 158 deg F)
5.	Compressor Filter Pressure Differential (0 psig  8 psig)
6.	Compressor Oil Separator Temperature (55 deg F  180 deg F)
7.	Compressor Motor  Amps (See Name Plate for Maximum Amps) 
8.	HPR level (10% - 79%)
9.	MTR level (11% - 68%)
10.	Compressor discharge pressure (Up to 190 psig while running)
11.	Compressor discharge temperature (Up to 200 deg F while running)
12.	Room Temperatures ( See Boars Head Policy: Room Temperature Policy)

SYSTEM STAGES
This system operates with one stage of compression.
ENGINE ROOM
Major equipment located inside the engine room includes:
	Five compressors (all Frick model RWBII-177 compressors @ 384 TR/ 410 BHP). 
	Two compressors (all Frick model RWFII-177H compressors @ 384 TR/ 410 BHP).
	One compressor (Frick model RWFII-100H compressor @ 135TR/ 213 BHP).
	One 36 dia. X 4'-6 horizontal thermosyphon pilot-receiver +95?F.
	One 96 dia. X 16'- 0 vertical high-pressure receiver +95?F.
	One 10 dia. X 30'- 0 vertical re-circulator package +20?F.
	One-Hansen APC Auto-Purger.


OUTSIDE ENGINE ROOM
Major equipment located on roof or in production areas includes: 
	Two EVAPCO model PMCB-544 condensers rated @ 10,053 MBH, for +20?FST/+95?FCT.
	Six EVAPCO model PMCB-530 condenser rated @ 5,026 MBH, for +20?FST/+95?FCT.



THERMOSYPHON PILOT-RECEIVER
The thermosyphon pilot-receiver is a horizontal high-pressure vessel. It is sized and used for storing a minimum five-minute supply of liquid ammonia for oil cooling and for separating liquid out of the return flow of ammonia from the thermosyphon oil coolers. The liqui

PROCESS & PROCESS CHEMISTRY
There are only two substances purposefully circulating in the system, ammonia (NH3) and an appropriate ammonia rated refrigeration compressor oil, all enclosed within ammonia compatible materials.  This refrigeration process is a closed system which prevents contact with other chemicals.  Refrigeration compressor oil is compatible and causes no chemical reaction with ammonia or system materials.
Refrigeration systems have no chemical reactions in the process cycle. The operation of a refrigeration system requires controlling the ammonia (NH3) refrigerant temperature and pressure at key points in the system. The ideal cycle considers heat transfer in the condenser and evaporator without pressure losses. The refrigerant leaves the evaporator as a low pressure, low temperature, and saturated vapor then enters the compressor, where the refrigerant is compressed to a high pressure, high temperature vapor and is sent to the condenser. The refrigerant leaves the condenser as a high pressure, medium temperature, saturated liquid, where the refrigerant enters an expansion valve and expands as it leaves. At this point, the refrigerant is at a low pressure, low temperature liquid entering the evaporator. Inside the evaporator, the refrigerant is evaporated at a constant pressure. Heat transfer to the evaporator and from the condenser occurs without a limited temperature difference between the refrigerant emitting the heat and the refrigerant that absorbs the heat. However, this is not true during the de-superheating process in the condenser.

CAPACITY
This food distribution facility operates a single temperature one-stage, anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigeration system with engine room compressor capacities of approximately 2600 TR at (+10-20?F) suction.

SYSTEM CLASSIFICATION
This refrigeration system is a liquid recirculation system and is designed to operate at an over-feed ratio of approximately 3:1 for all evaporators. Anhydrous ammonia (R-717)
